Description of incident: On November 12, 2017, we discovered that an employee had inadvertently responded to a phishing attack email, allowing an unauthorized person to create an email rule in that employee’s email account automatically forwarding incoming email to an unknown third party,  to date we have learned that the unauthorized access appears to date back to July 2017. Typically only the name of the worker was provided, or in some instances the name and the last four digits of the worker’s social security number with two exceptions: (i) for some workers accepted by the customer, the customer requested and received a follow up email with the first five digits of the worker’s social security number and date of birth, to complete the customer’s records; and (ii) for other workers, a customer confirmed the workers under consideration in a spreadsheet which included the worker’s name and social security number.
